title: Covered Interest Parity
equation_latex: \text{F} = \text{S} * (1 + r_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic) / (1 + r_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n)
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity. F represents the forward exchange rate, S is the spot exchange rate, r_domestic is the domestic interest rate, and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. CIP must hold to prevent arbitrage opportunities in the foreign exchange market. This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Uncovered Interest Parity
equation_latex: \text{E}[\text{F}] = \text{S} * (1 + r_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic - r_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n)
notes: This equation defines uncovered interest parity. E[F] represents the expected future spot rate, S is the current spot rate, r_domestic is the domestic interest rate, and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. UIP is a theoretical condition that often does not hold in practice. This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Forward Premium
equation_latex: \text{F} \times or \times wa \times rd \text{P} \times re \times mi \times um = (\text{F} - \text{S}) / \text{S}
notes: This equation calculates the forward premium or discount. Forward Premium represents the percentage difference between forward and spot rates. Positive values indicate the domestic currency is trading at a forward premium (stronger forward than spot).

title: Forward Discount
equation_latex: \text{F} \times or \times wa \times rd D \times is \times co \times un \times t = (\text{S} - \text{F}) / \text{S}
notes: This equation calculates the forward discount. Forward Discount represents the percentage by which the forward rate is below the spot rate. A forward discount indicates the domestic currency is expected to weaken. This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Continuous Covered Parity
equation_latex: \text{F} = \text{S} * e \times xp \times ((r_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic - r_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n) * \text{T})
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity with continuous compounding. F represents the forward rate, S is the spot rate, r_domestic and r_foreign are continuously compounded interest rates, and T is time to maturity. This form is widely used in derivatives pricing.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Value
equation_latex: V_{\text{F}}R \times A = N * (L - \text{K}) * d \times el \times ta * D \times \text{F}
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Forward Rate Agreement. V_FRA represents the mark-to-market value, N is the notional, L is the realized LIBOR rate, K is the agreed FRA rate, delta is the day count fraction, and DF is the discount factor.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Rate
equation_latex: \text{F} \times RA R \times at \times e = ((1 + r_{l}o \times ng * T_{l}o \times ng) / (1 + r_{s}h \times or \times t * T_{s}h \times or \times t) - 1) * (360 / d \times el \times ta)
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the FRA rate. FRA Rate represents the rate agreed in the FRA contract, r_long is the rate for the longer period, r_short is the rate for the shorter period, T_long and T_short are the year fractions, and delta is the day count in days.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Absolute)
equation_latex: \text{S} = P_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic / P_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines absolute purchasing power parity. S represents the exchange rate that equalizes the purchasing power of two currencies, P_domestic is the domestic price level, and P_foreign is the foreign price level. This is the law of one price applied to price levels.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Relative)
equation_latex: S_{1} / S_{0} = (1 + i \times nf \times la \times ti \times on_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic) / (1 + i \times nf \times la \times ti \times on_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines relative purchasing power parity. S_1/S_0 represents the change in the exchange rate, inflation_domestic is the domestic inflation rate, and inflation_foreign is the foreign inflation rate. This predicts how exchange rates adjust for inflation differentials.

title: Real Exchange Rate
equation_latex: R \times ER = \text{S} * (P_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n / P_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation calculates the real exchange rate. RER represents the relative price of goods across countries, S is the nominal exchange rate, P_foreign is the foreign price level, and P_domestic is the domestic price level. RER deviations from 1 indicate real exchange rate misalignment.

title: Big Mac Index
equation_latex: B \times ig \text{M} \times ac \text{P} \times PP = L \times oc \times al \text{P} \times ri \times ce / U \times \text{S} \text{P} \times ri \times ce
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines the Big Mac index methodology. Big Mac PPP represents the implied exchange rate based on Big Mac prices, Local Price is the Big Mac price in local currency, and US Price is the Big Mac price in the US. This provides a simple PPP benchmark.

title: FX Forward Valuation
equation_latex: V_{f}o \times rw \times ar \times d = (F_{m}a \times rk \times et - F_{t}h \times eo \times re \times ti \times ca \times l) * N * D \times \text{F}
notes: This equation calculates the value of an FX forward. V_forward represents the mark-to-market value, F_market is the market forward rate, F_theoretical is the contract forward rate, N is the notional, and DF is the discount factor.

title: Cross Rate
equation_latex: S_{c}r \times os \times s = S_{A}/B = S_{A}/U \times SD / S_{B}/U \times SD
notes: This equation calculates a cross exchange rate. S_cross represents the exchange rate between currencies A and B, S_A/USD is the rate between A and USD, and S_B/USD is the rate between B and USD. Cross rates are derived from rates against a common currency.

title: Triangular Arbitrage
equation_latex: S_{A}/B - S_{A}/U \times SD * S_{U}\text{S} \times D/B = 0
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage condition for triangular arbitrage. S_A/B represents the direct rate, S_A/USD and S_USD/B are cross rates through USD. Any arbitrage opportunities that deviation creates should be quickly eliminated.

title: Currency Option Delta (Call)
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta_{\text{C}} = e^{-q \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{1})
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency call option. Delta_C represents the sensitivity to the spot rate, q is the foreign risk-free rate, T is time to expiration, and N(d_1) is the cumulative normal distribution. Foreign currency options use the Garman-Kohlhagen model. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure.

title: Currency Option Delta (Put)
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta_{\text{P}} = -e^{-q \times \text{T}} * N \times (-d_{1})
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency put option. Delta_P represents the sensitivity to the spot rate, q is the foreign risk-free rate, T is time to expiration, and N(-d_1) is the cumulative normal. Put delta is negative, as put prices fall when the currency appreciates. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen Call Price
equation_latex: \text{C} = e^{-r_{d} \text{T}} * (\text{F} * N \times (d_{1}) - \text{K} * N \times (d_{2}))
notes: This equation prices a European currency call option using the Garman-Kohlhagen model. C represents the call price, r_d is the domestic rate, F is the forward rate, K is the strike, and N(d) are cumulative normal distributions. This extends Black-Scholes for two currencies.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen d_1
equation_latex: d_{1} = (l \times n \times (\text{F}/\text{K}) + 0.5 * s \times ig \times ma^{2} * \text{T}) / (s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation defines d_1 for the Garman-Kohlhagen model. d_1 combines the moneyness (ln(F/K)), volatility sigma, and time to expiration T. This parameter is used in both the call and put pricing formulas.

title: Currency Put-Call Parity
equation_latex: \text{C} + \text{K} * e^{-r_{d} \text{T}} = \text{P} + \text{F} * e^{-q \text{T}}
notes: This equation defines put-call parity for currency options. C and P are call and put prices, K is the strike, r_d is the domestic rate, q is the foreign rate, and F is the forward rate. This no-arbitrage relationship links call and put prices.

title: Carry Trade Return
equation_latex: R_{c}a \times rr \times y = (r_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n - r_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic) - (\text{E}[S_{\text{T}}] - S_{0}) / S_{0}
notes: This equation calculates the expected return from a carry trade. R_carry represents the expected return from borrowing in low-yield currencies and investing in high-yield currencies, r_foreign and r_domestic are interest rates, and the last term is expected depreciation.

title: Carry Trade Sharpe Ratio
equation_latex: \text{S} \times ha \times rp \times e = (r_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n - r_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic - s \times ig \times ma_{\text{S}} * s \times ig \times ma_{R} * r \times ho) / s \times ig \times ma_{c}a \times rr \times y
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for carry trades. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted carry return, r_foreign - r_domestic is the interest rate differential, sigma_S is spot volatility, sigma_R is the risk premium, rho is correlation, and sigma_carry is carry volatility.

title: FX Swap Points
equation_latex: \text{S} \times wa \times p \text{P} \times oi \times nt \times s = \text{F} - \text{S} = \text{S} * (r_{d} - r_{f}) * \text{T}
notes: This equation calculates the swap points for an FX swap. Swap Points represent the difference between forward and spot rates, which approximately equals the interest rate differential times the spot rate and time to maturity.

title: FX Implied Volatility
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{i}m \times pl \times ie \times d = s \times ig \times ma_{r}e \times al \times iz \times ed / s \times qr \times t \times (1 - r \times ho^{2})
notes: This equation relates implied to realized volatility for currency pairs. sigma_implied represents the volatility implied by option prices, sigma_realized is historical volatility, and rho is the correlation between spot returns and volatility. Implied volatility is typically higher for currencies.

title: Currency Basis
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ur \times re \times nc \times y B \times as \times is = F_{m}a \times rk \times et - F_{\text{C}}\text{I} \times \text{P}
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the currency basis in cross-currency swaps. Currency Basis represents the deviation from covered interest parity, F_market is the market forward rate, and F_CIP is the CIP-implied forward. A positive basis indicates funding pressure in the foreign currency.

title: Cross Currency Swap Spread
equation_latex: \text{C} \times CS \text{S} \times pr \times ea \times d = R_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic - R_{f}o \times re \times ig \times n - (S_{0} - F_{\text{C}}\text{I} \times \text{P}) / S_{0}
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the cross-currency swap spread. CCS Spread represents the differential between domestic and foreign rates adjusted for the forward points, R_domestic and R_foreign are rates, S_0 is spot, and F_CIP is the CIP forward.

title: FX Risk Reversal
equation_latex: R \times is \times k R \times ev \times er \times sa \times l = \text{C} \times al \times l \text{V} \times ol - \text{P} \times ut \text{V} \times ol
notes: This equation calculates the FX risk reversal. Risk Reversal represents the volatility difference between out-of-the-money calls and puts, which indicates market skew. Positive risk reversal means calls are more expensive (market expects currency appreciation).

title: FX Butterfly
equation_latex: B \times ut \times te \times rf \times ly = (A \times tM \text{V} \times ol + 25 \times D \text{C} \times al \times l \text{V} \times ol + 25 \times D \text{P} \times ut \text{V} \times ol) / 3 - A \times tM \text{V} \times ol
notes: This equation calculates the FX butterfly spread. Butterfly represents the curvature of the volatility smile, AtM Vol is at-the-money volatility, and 25D Call/Put are 25-delta option volatilities. This measures the smile curvature.

title: FX Delta Neutral Straddle
equation_latex: \text{S} \times tr \times ad \times dl \times e = \text{C} \times al \times l \times (25 \times D) + \text{P} \times ut \times (25 \times D)
notes: This equation describes a delta-neutral straddle using 25-delta options. Straddle represents buying equal amounts of 25-delta calls and puts to create a position that profits from volatility regardless of direction. This is a common volatility trading strategy. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure.

title: NDF Valuation
equation_latex: V_{N}D \times \text{F} = N * (S_{m}a \times rk \times et - S_{s}t \times ri \times ke) * D \times F_{d}o \times me \times st \times ic
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Non-Deliverable Forward. V_NDF represents the mark-to-market value, N is the notional in USD, S_market is the current NDF rate, S_strike is the contract rate, and DF_domestic is the domestic discount factor. NDFs are settled in USD.

title: FX Delta Exposure
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta \text{E} \times xp \times os \times ur \times e = \text{P} \times os \times it \times io \times n \text{S} \times iz \times e * D \times el \times ta * S_{0}
notes: This equation calculates the delta exposure in FX. Delta Exposure represents the equivalent spot position, Position Size is the option notional, Delta is the option delta, and S_0 is the spot rate. This is used for hedging and risk management. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure.
